column3: Great camera! Solid, well built and such a beautiful design. EVF is brilliant.  Great vari-angle monitor and a wealth of features. A joy to hold and use. With good lenses this camera is producing stunning results for me at a faction of the size and weight of my old Canon EOS bodies and EF lenses.

column3: Superb image quality and high iso performance. Excellent auto-focus performance even in very  dim light conditions. 9 frames a sec. that's fast, viewfinder very good and clear, works fine and very useful to operate in very light conditions. Stylish  retro design is a must and together with a sturdy and robust build quality makes this camera an exceptional device. Solid and a joy to use. Matches my canon 7D image quality, fact. Iso 1600, 3200, 6400 are excellent. This time Olympus really level up the game. I love my OM-D

This camera is one damn good camera. I purchased to become my secondary camera; however, the way it handles it may become my first camera and my DSLR will become the secondary camera. I have used it on one pro job and it performed brilliantly; I was taking a real chance using it, as if it hadn't - then I would have upset my client and lost quite a bit of money and as a professional photographer, I don't want to do that.

It's obviously never gonna be up there with the dlsr in picture quality, but for it's size it is amazing, and with the build and shooting experience, i've gone for this over my dslr a few times.

column3: To me, this is an almost perfect compromise between portability, features and quality. It is (just) pocketable, the focal range is very useful, the level of manual control excellent and the quality of the images produced very, very good indeed for such a small camera with a small sensor. I think a lot of this is down to the excellent lens Olympus have chosen. Has it totally replaced my Canon 7D SLR? No, but it gets pretty close for most uses and unlike the 7D it is now always with me when I need it.

column3: Stunning build quality when compared with the competition, in black it looks understated and expensive. The auto focus usually gets the right subject and it's not too hard to force it to pick up on the right detail. This this is more crucial than usual as the quality zoom and fast lens combine with the larger than average sensor to allow for some decent depth of field control from a compact camera. You don't have to try too hard to take great shots.
column5: Whilst the lens cap gives the camera an aura of semi pro-ness (if you'll forgive the word), it's a bit fiddly in reality. The control dial is easily changed - this is a real niggle as you can leave the camera in aperture priority mode, chuck it in your jeans pocket then take it out without realising it set itself to shutter priority mode, etc.

column3: On the manual settings you have full control of aperture, shutter speed and focal point and on the art filter settings you have control of focal point.  All of these settings allow you to shoot in macro and super macro.  There is a large range of preset programs, so if you just want to point and shoot this camera covers every adventurality.  The colour and the resulting images are awesome particularly for a compact camera.  There are six art filters which gives the user more creative experimentation.  Art filter 6 called dramatic is particulally impressive as it changes dull overcast cloud into stormy moody clouds.
column5: Limited zoom (X4), Short battery life (two and a half hours of continus shooting)

column3: Really good image quality for a compact, and a good solid feel in use (It's a metal body). Can be as easy to use as you want with good auto and programme settings, but can very quickly become a real 'photographer's camera' with easy access to a wide range of settings. Contrary to some reviews you do NOT need to go into the menus to change these. There is also a number of Art Filters, which apply stylised treatment to your shots. No one will like them all, but I suspect everyone will fancy a couple of styles.
column5: Not much to moan about. Shutter lag could be better. Compact users will find the lens cap a pain, but DSLR users won't even notice! The body size makes it good to handle but it has proved difficult to get a case to fit well.

column3: . I'm an enthuasist, I was considering a micro4/3 but when I compared the image quality and performance, i was convinced of getting this little amazing camera. In future it's reasonable to consider the wide variety of lens adapters. There are for example a 0,25 fisheye-magnifier and a 1.7x tele converter for a cheap price. So I don't think the 28mm will be an issue.
column5: A little too simplified. Firmware not up to date. Video mode a little dissapointing.

column3: The F1.8 - 2.5 lens is he main reason I purchased this camera (upgrading from Canon S95) but even so I was still surprised at just how much difference this makes to shooitng options, especially at zoom end. I rarely need to go above 400 ISO, which is good because I have to say that I prefer the Canon S95 jpeg compression. The built in Neutral Density filter is good bonus. I did not expect to use the Art Filters or Scenes but the Dramtic Tone and Panorama are actually quite fun. The burst speed is great and another advantage over the S95.
column5: In manual mode the screen adjusts to show approxiate exposure as a live view, but only within a 2 stop range (the S95 has no such range limit)

column3: I have been using cameras for 48 years. This is as easy and straightforward a camera as any I have used, whether DSLR, SLR or any other type. It is light, small, easy to carry. The lenses are as good as any I have had before. Despite problems I got another before I had it repaired. I had always been a Canon man until now but the Olympus is so much cheaper and lighter with images just as sharp I am a convert.

column3: The world's smallest Digital SLR, but it's still reassuringly chuncky. Easy to use with lots of features. Indoor images will certainly impress if you're used to a point and shoot. Handles lighting more accurately. Starts up nalmost immediately. Unlike it's rivals at this price, it also comes with Live View so you can 'see' the image before it's taken. Comes with a training DVD - very helpful. You can buy many accessories off Ebay, such as filters and screen protectors. This is pretty much the same camera as the more expensive Olympus models but at a cheaper price, so a bargin.

column3: I bought this camera specifically with a planned holiday to jamaica in mind. column3: I've used this camera while on holidays and because the zoom is so good I've being able to get amazing landscape pictures and pictures I was unable to capture with my previous cameras. options which can bring a completely different angle to your shots. The pop art and drawing one in particular impress me. The movie mode is also a great new addition. The microphone picks up voice and music very well. The image quality is second to none on the photos I have taken and I am looking forward to taking it on holiday with me as so far I've just been taking it out on test shoots. The playback fuctions are clear and easy to understand and the camera as a whole looks great and is easy to handle. It has a large LCD screen which clearly shows the mode/shooting categories that you are in for each shot. Post shot, it displays all of the shot information so you can pick and chose the best settings for future shots in the same conditions. I would recommend this camera to anyone who has an interest in photography.

column5: Only a few niggles with this camera, for one, some of the modes aren't so good for example pet mode, makes the image go very grainy which is a shame as the images on for example beauty come out absolutely faultless and another niggle is the recording. For some reason, alot of cameras these days do not zoom in and out whilst filming, this is one of them, which is a shame or it would be perfect. But i find this a very key point in any camera, you want to be able to zoom in and out of your subjects and if your subject comes closer you have to stop filming and change the zoom then record again. I'm sure the SP-600UZ did zoom in and out whist recording when i tried it in the shop but i cannot be sure for definite, i'd like to know why they haven't put this key element in.

This Olympus VR320 camera has a good zoom (12.5x = to 300mm on a 35mm camera). It has an antishake function which works well, but on nearing full zoom I would recommend uusing a steady or tripod. SDHC Cards are available quite cheap and I recommend you get the fastest speed card you can afford. I'm using a Sandisk 45mb/sec class 10 card. I found the speed of the pictures taken was supprisingly quick. It fits in your pocket and is quick to start up. It takes resonable video at 720, but I have yet to play them back on a TV. It does not have an HDMI socket. The Auto Scene function is very good, leaving you to be able and point and shoot. It also has other modes that you can use as you gain experience. It has taken good pictures even in low light. I have had Olympus cameras before, but the menu on this camera is much easier to use than previous models I have had. Having a choice of colours is good. For a 12.5x camera st this price, that fits in your pocket, I would recommend it highly.
column5: This camera does not have a seperate battery charger, the battery is charged in the camera, although seperate battery chargers are available. It is not Shower Proof. It can be a bit fiddly to hold, shame Olympus did not put a few rubber grip strips on it.

column3: The Olympus PEN e-p1 packs in the option of SLR *AND* 'point-and-shoot' functionality with lots of 'extras' into a very compact very nice 'retro' design. Image quality is brilliant. For the nicer look, go for the silver rather than the black 14-42mm lens and don't bother buying the fixed pancake lens (available as an accessory) which has no zoom range (so totally pointless). If you buy any additional four thirds zoom lenses, don't forget you'll also need to buy the MMF-1 adapter as this camera is built to take 'micro'- four thirds lens, therefore *not* the same size as standard 'four-thirds'. Battery will last for two days of moderate usage, so I would recommend buying a spare battery. Also, the brown leather body-case and strap and soft brown leather retro bags (in three sizes) are all very nice - if pricey - accessories in keeping with the camera's classic design. The flash is only necessary if you anticipate taking photos in *very* low light conditions. Otherwise, you can compensate for low light by adjusting the shutter speed. I highly recommend this camera!
column5: Only down-side is lack of view-finder. However, it's no great loss if you prefer to use the screen anyway. The only place where you might miss it is very bright conditions. However, as long as you have reasonable eye-sight, you can still see the image even in bright sun-light. The view-finder which you can buy for it is a little pointless as you can only view a single fixed frame - a bit like like the old automatic camera view-finders.

column3: Great Retro look
column5: Not brilliant at high ISO unless you have fast lenses

column3: I researched it thoroughly before buying, and there are (generally) some issues that have appeared in the reviews that need addressing. 1) lack of flash, 2) poor/slow focus and 3) a low quality screen that is difficult to see in bright light (hence the viewfinder on the EP2). 1) The lack of flash isn't an issue for the more advanced photographer, they are largely unnecessary, but a lack of a fast lens (see below) is an issue. 2) This has been greatly improved by firmware updates, but it still has issues in some low light situations. 3) not an issue at all. I have tried looking at it from all angles in bright sunlight - the image is still perfectly usable! Finally at half the price of the original RRP (and the EP2), this is the bargain of the year
column5: The final point (which is not really a negative) is about the camera as a DSLR replacement. It is certainly not that. As a general camera, it is brilliant, but for the more challenging images a DSLR will still be the camera of choice. Remember, it is not a compact, it is not a DSLR. It is a PEN.

I upgraded from an Olympus 1030 and the operation appears to be much easier now to use it underwater.  You can switch from still to cine with one button (no need anymore to remember how many clicks of the function wheel). The menu is much more intuitive with regard to changing flash setting say.  I have yet to use it underwater, but so far on dry land I am very pleased.
column5: I have modified the wrist strap on both cameras by adding a cord ring  - so that I can slip the strap over my wrist then use the cord ring to tighten it to my wrist.  I was unhappy in taking the  it below the waves without the assurance that I would not loose it down below. The weight has also gone up which I am not too happy with.  I liked the idea of the previous model of having the photos recorded on the XD cards.  This meant that your could buy new cards if you wanted to and use the old one to store images until you had time to archive them properly.  Now you have to download them to say your hard disc on a regular basis.  Not so secure if you were to get hard disc problems - and had not backed up recently.  I can probably get used to the new way or working.

A novice to digital photography may find it a bit confusing with the scroll options for different functions. column3: I had the old model of this camera and you can really see an improvement in the quality of the pictures with this model. I also like the large screen and the different scene settings and effects you can use (the 'fishbowl' and 'punk' modes made my friends and I laugh a lot!). It's slim and light and I love the vibrant pink colour. Overall I really like it and would recommend to anyone looking for a reasonably priced camera that is generally simple to use.
column5: I was disappointed when I realised that the camera only takes SD/SHDC cards, rather than the XD card the previous camera had, which meant having to spend extra money. I would also prefer if there was a separate battery charger as with the old model, rather than having to plug the camera into a laptop. Also, I have only used the video a couple of times but I couldn't work out how to stop filming at first. My friend used the camera and also had the same problem. It has also taken a while to get used to locating everything, although that's probably due to having to adjust from the old model that I was used to.

column5: I bought this camera after my brother has it and likes it, but he is'nt really into photography like i am and is happy with most of his holiday snaps being blurry and not of great quality. I on the other hand wanted a 'tough' compact camera to use in the situations when i don't want to take my DSLR. So i bought this camera, and was so disappointed. Firstly it's like a brick, it's really heavy and has very sharp corners. The shutter button is very hard to press down resulting in a bit of camera shake when you take a photo, with no vibration reduction to correct it. The menu/features button on the back is in the form of a joystick which is really quite hard to use, and you end up selecting different options than you actually wanted. It's also really slow, from turning it on, to it being ready to take a photo, is such a long time, by which time the moment will have passed. I also think the image quality is terrible unless you really take the time to hold the camera really steadily, which a lot of the time when trying to take a quick picture, isn't possible. On a night out recently i think 1 in every 4 photos were blurry. Overall, i think its a terrible camera and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. I ended up getting the Nikon AW100 which is miles better.

I found this camera, worked well.  I had two batteries and would keep one next to my body and managed several picturess, before the cold kicked in, I wold then swap the batteries and use them turn and turn about.  The camera is robust, easy to use with a feature for 'Beach and Snow' good for me of course.  The compact design meant there was little to go wrong or suffer from cold damage.

column3: I've used several Olympus cameras in the past (work camera), and so I'm familiar with the menu and layout.  Easy to use in this respect.  Camera is a good size and not too weighty.  LCD display is easy to use and a good size.
column5: I have to use Olympus cameras as part of my work, because our company use Camedia and will not support any other camera type.  Unfortunately, this camera is terrible, and if I could, I would use another brand at the drop of a hat.  Long delay between pressing the button and the picture being taken.  Most of my photos turn out blurred, despite half-pressing the button to engage the auto-focus before taking a photo (as recommended).  Blueish halo-effect around buildings, where they meet sky.  Overall, extremely disappointing, as I like to take many photos of the places I've visited and more often than not, the photographs are poor.  This camera appears to produce the same results as the 3 previous digital Olympus models I've used.

column3: A few to mention so i will attempt to condense. The f1.8-2.7 lens is really a boon to have. Allows so much more light into camera at all focal lenghs. The control ring around the lens so useful and adaptable. A max of 12mps on a small sensor allows for much better image quality that those silly larger numbers favoured by so many others. Raw support. A Must Have. Numerous adjustments to be made on settings. Even the Flash !! Real Fast Auto Focusing. I mean Fast !! compatibility with uhs 1 cards meaning it can rattle of continous shots at 5fps without slowing down or dropping frames for...well i gave in at like 60 shots. Image quality for photos up to iso 800 to me appear Excellent. Even up to 1000 iso is still Great. Yes. it does these small incrimentals on the iso scale. Being able to Cap ISO at your choose preference another major plus. The scroll wheel at the back working in conjunction with the control wheel upfont for instant adjustments. So Useful. The Clear and Bright Touch Screen with its ability to Touch focus and Capture instantly. Low light photography another plus. Bokeh due to that Fast lens another plus as is its riduculously close macro shooting ability. its Creative Arts and Scenes mode . Full manual controls. A very good iauto Function for those who are initially overwhelmed by the manual Choices present. Have i mentioned that its Video capability is just as Awesome as its stills functions. full 1080p at 30fps is available here and the results look real impressive on its screen and even more so on a HDTV . Oh the xz10  Is small almost discreet and that certainly makes it a carry anywhere pocket camera . Theres even more to praise about this camera  but i have said enough already and i think you can rightly assume i HIGHLY RECOMMEND it . Well Done Olympus. You've made me a Fan Boy.

column3: This is the type of digital camera I've been waiting for. A compact with an SLR size sensor and lens system. For outdoor use, up mountains and on moorland, it easily hangs beneath a coat with it's flat profile ready for quick use. The controls are well thought out, and to use in A or S modes it can adjusted as easily and quickly as  the old 35mm compacts could. Equally easy to access are the pre-set shooting modes, but they don't dominate it's use as do the pocket compacts. If you ever owned an Agfa Silette, Kodak Retinette 35mm compact, or even an original PEN you'll  love this little Olympus gem.

The camera offers all of the same automatic features as are on a regular Olympus compact (based on Olympus FE230) plus the more sophistacated manual options you would expect to find with a DSLR.
column5: It not easy to find fault with this camera kit. There are only two points. 1) Grip on the camera's body is a little bit awkward, making it difficult to hold it for a long time. However, the camera is very light-weight in relativity to other DSLRs, and the strap makes it comfortable when walking around. 2) I cannot, as of yet, find out how to put the autofocus off, which is a little bit annoying. But, seeing as these are the only faults i can pick out, it really is very good!

column3: Size. Excellent range of features. Easy and intuitive operation. Almost faultless and quick autofocus. New 'gradation mode' makes a real difference to wide contrast ranges such as in landscapes. Noise levels are very low and subtle. Auto white ballance is excellent outdoors (not tested indoors yet). Improved processing makes for more saturated and natural colours. The vivid setting is only needed when conditions mean colours could do with a boost eg flat dull light. Nothing on the market can touch it at this price.
column5: Small viewfinder, but you do get used to it. Diopter range too low. Very short-sighted users may need additional correction. LCD screen resolution could be better. Olympus tend towards a softer look to images, which is not to everyone's taste. Increasing sharpness by one step makes images look sharper with no aparent increase in noise or artifacts. Very susceptible to UV, so a 'haze filter' is a must. The omission of optical image stabalization may put some people off. All very minor gripes.

10.	Price.  There are cheaper options that will suit many photographers.  For those who want an everyday camera with all (or most) of the creative control of a DSLR then the E-P3 is worth serious consideration.  If you're upgrading from a point-and-shoot and just want better image quality then the high price will be harder to justify.  As a second camera for DSLR shooters you are making a considerable investment in a second camera system.  But equally for these people there will be an expectation of build quality, handling, creative control and image quality that never comes cheap

column3: I had to write this one because my PEN e-P3 exceeded my expectations--which doesn't happen very often. First, this camera is like a Faberge jewel. It is beautifully crafted with great attention to detail. Of course it would be worthless if it was only eye candy. I was expecting to have to shoot RAW files, but the out of camera JPEGS are amazing. Plus if you want to fine tune the JPEG the settings allow you two tweak them to suit your sensibility. ISO up to 1600 looks terrific and if you are in a jam the higher ISOs are useable. The OLED viewfinder is iPhone quality gorgeous. And while I thought the touchscreen interface was a feature that I wouldn't use, it is thoughtfully configured and more importantly responsive. Most reviews rave about the lightening fast focus...and I agree. There' s a little hunting and pecking at incredibly low light levels but manual focusing is easy. I am crazy happy with my PEN. I spent months doing research and I am so glad I chose this over DSLRs. You will not be disappointed!
Excellent quality of photography, with a lot of possibilities to give free rein to the creativity.

column5: The oblong plastic surround, around the lens looks a little fragile.  There is a removable ring around the lens which can be removed for lens accessories however I do not see many people using this feature and this part of the camera can hold tiny amounts of water as the ring compartment is not water resistant.  The plastic cover for the monitor screen at the back of the camera is probably better than toughened glass as it would give on impact.  As with all camera monitors in bright light, one can only uses it as a guide.

column3: I was looking for a next step up from my semi-SLR and something that was not too heavy on my wrists.  This olympus fit my specs and more.  It's supposedly olympus's lightest weight slr.  My previous camera was an olympus so finding my way around the buttons and functions was pretty intuitive.  Nothing so far has annoyed me yet but I've only had it a few days.
column5: Not really a bad point as such, but it doesn't take the same type of lithium battery as my old camera or my brother's E30 so it's going to be annoying to have to buy new spares.  The charger is also huge relative to the battery which will make it annoying to carry round.

column3: The camera offers a wide range of 23 different shooting modes (portrait, landscape, close-up, night shooting, etc) and automatic exposure which will be of great use to the beginner, whilst the options of aperture priority, shutter priority and fully-manual exposure will not restrict the more accomplished user. There is also an optional choice of 7 different art filters such as soft-focus to help create special moods without using image processing software. The more serious photographer will also appreciate the auto-focus options available. The 12.3 megapixels make for high-definition, quality photographs. The camera comes packaged with battery and charger, USB and Video cables, shoulder strap and Olympus Image Processing software for easy download and editing on a laptop or PC, and a comprehensive, well-written and easy-to-use instruction manual. Price-wise the whole package and the spec of the camera compare extremely favourably with anything else available. I have enjoyed using Olympus SLR and DSLR cameras for many years and this is as fine a camera as they have produced.
column5: Like any DSLR, the range of facilities and functions available may be rather daunting to the absolute beginner and for that reason I would hesitate to recommend this camera for a complete novice. However for anyone who has used SLRs or DSLRs before, or anyone wising to step up from top-end fixed-lens zoom digitals I could not think of any bad points to warn about.

column3: digital SLR, particularly the E420 as it was the best on the market. I was pleased to find that it could be used like a manually operated film camera where you decide on the aperture, shutter speed etc, or you could go into automatic mode with its 18 different scene modes. It is light and compact and even though I have large hands its small size is not a problem as far as operating it is concerned.  The back up instructions of both DVD and manual are easily understood
column5: I haven't come across any yet as far as the camera is concerned.  However the manual although instructive and relatively easily understood could have been better set out e.g after the first eight pages describing with diagrams the camera, the mode dial, the viewfinder, super control panel etc it then instructs you to unpack the box contents! Then after a few pages on attaching the lens, loading the card, shooting etc, the Table of Contents follows!   Throughout the rest of the manual was the frustration of starting to read about, for example White Balance only to be directed elsewhere in the manual for the selection of such.  Why not put it all in the same place?  Maybe I'm being a little too pedantic but I did find myself getting increasingly annoyed as I tried to follow  specific aspects of operation through the manual.
